media:group.media:title: What are...homology spheres?
media:group.media:description:
Goal. Explaining basic concepts of geometric topology in an intuitive way.
This time. What are...homology spheres? Or: Spheres, but not really...
Disclaimer. Nobody is perfect, and I might have said something silly. If there is any doubt, then please check the references.
Disclaimer. Geometric topology is usually the study of manifolds. This can mean manifold things ;-) So to be precise, this video series is mostly about knots, surfaces, three and four manifolds.
Slides. http://www.dtubbenhauer.com/youtube.html
Website with exercises. http://www.dtubbenhauer.com/lecture-geotop-2022.html
Thumbnail. https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/ec/Soccer_ball.svg/600px-Soccer_ball.svg.png
Geometric topology. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometric_topology https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_geometric_topology_topics https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manifold https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_(mathematics) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surface_(topology) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-manifold
Concepts in geometric topology. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_invariant https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braid_group https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_characteristic https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mapping_class_group https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exotic_sphere https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_conjecture https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thurston%27s_geometrization_conjecture https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cobordism https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unknotting_problem
Applications of geometric topology. https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/27051/applications-of-geometric-topology-to-theoretical-physics https://mathoverflow.net/questions/48222/applications-of-knot-theory https://math.mit.edu/research/highschool/primes/circle/documents/2019/Lim_Martin_2019.pdf
The wild world of three manifolds. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-manifold https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:3-manifolds https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homology_sphere https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolic_3-manifold https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_complement https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heegaard_splitting https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolization_theorem https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_conjecture https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometrization_conjecture https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4jdmkUQDWtQ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PlVQ8cn5fnw https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a_xErJctCYw
Dehn surgery. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dehn_surgery Section 2 of https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en
Homology spheres. Sections 2 and 3 of https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homology_sphere https://blogs.scientificamerican.com/roots-of-unity/a-few-of-my-favorite-spaces-the-poincare-homology-sphere/ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brieskorn_manifold
Pictures used. Picture from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QanLUNiqZW0 https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/ec/Soccer_ball.svg/600px-Soccer_ball.svg.png Pictures from https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en
Some books I am using (I sometimes steal some pictures from there). https://www.math.cuhk.edu.hk/course_builder/1920/math4900e/Adams--The%20Knot%20Book.pdf https://arxiv.org/abs/1610.02592?context=math https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9781400865321/html?lang=en https://bookstore.ams.org/fourman https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en https://bookstore.ams.org/surv-55 https://bookstore.ams.org/gsm-20
KnotAtlas. http://katlas.math.toronto.edu/wiki/The_Rolfsen_Knot_Table
SnapPy. https://snappy.math.uic.edu/
Mathematica. http://katlas.org/wiki/The_Mathematica_Package_KnotTheory%60 https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/ChartForATorus/
SageMath. https://doc.sagemath.org/html/en/reference/knots/sage/knots/knot.html
#geometrictopology #topology #mathematics

media:group.media:title: What is...homotopy of spheres?
media:group.media:description:
Goal. I would like to tell you a bit about my favorite theorems, ideas or concepts in mathematics and why I like them so much.
This time. What is...homotopy of spheres? Or: Surprisingly hard!?
Disclaimer. Nobody is perfect, and I might have said something silly. If there is any doubt, then please check the references.
Slides. http://www.dtubbenhauer.com/youtube.html
Thumbnail. https://web.ma.utexas.edu/users/richard.wong/researchimages/homotopy_groups_of_spheres.png https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/ec/Soccer_ball.svg/600px-Soccer_ball.svg.png
Main discussion. https://pi.math.cornell.edu/~hatcher/AT/AT.pdf https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homotopy_group https://www.mathphysicsbook.com/mathematics/algebraic-topology/counting-the-ways-a-sphere-maps-to-a-space/the-higher-homotopy-groups/ https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fundamental_group https://math.unice.fr/~indira/Mygifs.html https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eckmann%E2%80%93Hilton_argument https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hopf_fibration https://arxiv.org/pdf/1304.7705.pdf https://arxiv.org/pdf/1211.3093.pdf
Mathoverflow likes this topic. https://mathoverflow.net/questions/22837/what-are-the-uses-of-the-homotopy-groups-of-spheres https://mathoverflow.net/questions/22688/why-the-heck-are-the-homotopy-groups-of-the-sphere-so-damn-complicated https://mathoverflow.net/questions/130922/what-is-the-31st-homotopy-group-of-the-2-sphere https://mathoverflow.net/questions/31004/computational-complexity-of-computing-homotopy-groups-of-spheres https://mathoverflow.net/questions/16495/applications-of-homotopy-groups-of-spheres
Mathematica. https://mathworld.wolfram.com/HomotopyGroup.html
Pictures used. https://math.unice.fr/~indira/GIFS/Pi1.gif https://www.mathphysicsbook.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/01/31.higher-homotopy.png https://web.ma.utexas.edu/users/richard.wong/researchimages/homotopy_groups_of_spheres.png https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/ec/Soccer_ball.svg/600px-Soccer_ball.svg.png https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Simply_connected_space#/media/File:P1S2all.jpg https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hopf_fibration#/media/File:Hopfkeyrings.jpg
YouTube and co. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dy0ZOEe8u-E (shameful self-promotion) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RS7986o6F14 (more shameful self-promotion) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MYr2NBjrYh0 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=TfxztmYuq_o

entry.title: Daniel Tubbenhauer: Representations of monoidal categories

media:group.media:title: Daniel Tubbenhauer: Representations of monoidal categories
media:group.media:description:
There is a MathOverflow question with title "Why aren't representations of monoids studied so much?''. Well, I do not know, but it can't be because the theory is bad. In fact, there is a well-developed theory that is about 80 years old, and this theory is almost as smooth and beautiful as group representation theory itself.
There are even categorifications of it: What categorifies monoids? For example monoidal categories. And indeed the representation theory of monoids categorifies to representation theory of monoidal categories.
This talk is a friendly overview of the representation theory of monoidal categories with no prior knowledge about this theory assumed.

media:group.media:title: What is...Hamming distance?
media:group.media:description:
Goal. I would like to tell you a bit about my favorite theorems, ideas or concepts in mathematics and why I like them so much.
This time. What is...Hamming distance? Or: Cubes!
Disclaimer. Nobody is perfect, and I might have said something silly. If there is any doubt, then please check the references.
Slides. http://www.dtubbenhauer.com/youtube.html
Thumbnail. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming(7,4)#/media/File:Hamming(7,4)_example_0110.svg
Main discussion. https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/6772729 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming_distance https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming_space https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming_code https://doi.org/10.1371%2Fjournal.pmed.0050069 https://cs.stackexchange.com/questions/32025/hamming-distance-required-for-error-detection-and-correction https://medium.com/geekculture/total-hamming-distance-problem-1b74decd71c9
Error correction and friends. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alphabet_(formal_languages) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_language#Words_over_an_alphabet https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/String_metric https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edit_distance https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Error_detection_and_correction https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming(7,4) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Block_code https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coding_theory https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Coding_theory https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gap-Hamming_problem
Mathematica. https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/PatternsProducedByHammingDistance/ https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/TheHamming74Code/ https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/DistanceAndDissimilarityPatterns/ https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/CorrectionTrees/
Pictures used. https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Mathieu-Clabaut-2/publication/292980312/figure/fig1/AS:669394522869781@1536607499740/Mathematical-formal-language-as-the-best-compromise-between-human-and-computer.png Picture from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming_distance https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming_distance#/media/File:Hamming_distance_3_bit_binary.svg https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming(7,4)#/media/File:Hamming(7,4).svg https://labster-image-manager.s3.amazonaws.com/v2/NAP/000bb75b-301f-40ff-bc36-be52ef5fb474/NAP_DNACode.en.x1024.png https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamming(7,4)#/media/File:Hamming(7,4)_example_0110.svg

media:group.media:title: What is...the jeu de taquin?
media:group.media:description:
Goal. I would like to tell you a bit about my favorite theorems, ideas or concepts in mathematics and why I like them so much.
This time. What is...the jeu de taquin? Or: Teasing permutations.
Disclaimer. Nobody is perfect, and I might have said something silly. If there is any doubt, then please check the references.
Slides. http://www.dtubbenhauer.com/youtube.html
Thumbnail. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/15_puzzle#/media/File:15-puzzle_magical.svg
Main discussion. https://encyclopediaofmath.org/index.php?title=Jeu_de_taquin https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jeu_de_taquin https://encyclopediaofmath.org/index.php?title=Jeu_de_taquin https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Young_tableau#Skew_tableaux https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robinson%E2%80%93Schensted%E2%80%93Knuth_correspondence https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plactic_monoid Section 3.7 of https://link.springer.com/book/10.1007/978-1-4757-6804-6
The game. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/15_puzzle https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taquin
Symmetric group. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Symmetric_group https://mathworld.wolfram.com/SymmetricGroup.html
Robinson-Schensted (sometimes + Knuth) correspondence. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robinson%E2%80%93Schensted_correspondence https://encyclopediaofmath.org/wiki/Robinson-Schensted_correspondence https://www.symmetricfunctions.com/rsk.htm https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robinson%E2%80%93Schensted%E2%80%93Knuth_correspondence https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Viennot%27s_geometric_construction
Representation theory of symmetric groups. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representation_theory_of_the_symmetric_group https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Young_tableau https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partition_(number_theory)#Representations_of_partitions https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partition_(number_theory) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specht_module https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hook_length_formula https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Young%27s_lattice
Mathematica. https://reference.wolfram.com/language/Combinatorica/ref/PermutationToTableaux.html
Pictures used. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/15_puzzle#/media/File:15-puzzle_magical.svg https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/15-puzzle-02.jpg/220px-15-puzzle-02.jpg https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Skew_tableau_5422-21.svg/150px-Skew_tableau_5422-21.svg.png https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/Jeu_de_taquin.svg/1920px-Jeu_de_taquin.svg.png Picture from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IhL76jDesg4 https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plate_tectonics#/media/File:Plates_tect2_en.svg
YouTube and co. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IhL76jDesg4 (shameful self promotion) https://www.integral-domain.org/lwilliams/Applets/RSKPermutations.html https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K_qhmSO7giQ (and the rest of the series) https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Nl1WGWx0Wvs

media:group.media:title: What is...Kirby calculus?
media:group.media:description:
Goal. Explaining basic concepts of geometric topology in an intuitive way.
This time. What is...Kirby calculus? Or: Knots and three manifolds, part 2.
Disclaimer. Nobody is perfect, and I might have said something silly. If there is any doubt, then please check the references.
Disclaimer. Geometric topology is usually the study of manifolds. This can mean manifold things ;-) So to be precise, this video series is mostly about knots, surfaces, three and four manifolds.
Slides. http://www.dtubbenhauer.com/youtube.html
Website with exercises. http://www.dtubbenhauer.com/lecture-geotop-2022.html
Thumbnail. Picture from https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en
Geometric topology. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometric_topology https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_geometric_topology_topics https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manifold https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_(mathematics) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surface_(topology) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-manifold
Concepts in geometric topology. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_invariant https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braid_group https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_characteristic https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mapping_class_group https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exotic_sphere https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_conjecture https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thurston%27s_geometrization_conjecture https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cobordism https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unknotting_problem
Applications of geometric topology. https://physics.stackexchange.com/questions/27051/applications-of-geometric-topology-to-theoretical-physics https://mathoverflow.net/questions/48222/applications-of-knot-theory https://math.mit.edu/research/highschool/primes/circle/documents/2019/Lim_Martin_2019.pdf
The wild world of three manifolds. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/3-manifold https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:3-manifolds https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Homology_sphere https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolic_3-manifold https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knot_complement https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heegaard_splitting https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hyperbolization_theorem https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poincar%C3%A9_conjecture https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geometrization_conjecture https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4jdmkUQDWtQ https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PlVQ8cn5fnw https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a_xErJctCYw
Dehn surgery. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dehn_surgery Section 2 of https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en
Kirby calculus. Section 3 of https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirby_calculus https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/Kirby+calculus https://mathoverflow.net/questions/30972/kirby-calculus-and-local-moves https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01406222 https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0040938379900107?via%3Dihub
Pictures used. https://i.stack.imgur.com/JJXlB.png https://media.springernature.com/lw685/springer-static/image/art%3A10.1007%2Fs00283-020-09990-0/MediaObjects/283_2020_9990_Fig4_HTML.png Picture from https://www.dtubbenhauer.com/qinvariants.pdf Pictures from https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en
Some books I am using (I sometimes steal some pictures from there). https://www.math.cuhk.edu.hk/course_builder/1920/math4900e/Adams--The%20Knot%20Book.pdf https://arxiv.org/abs/1610.02592?context=math https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9781400865321/html?lang=en https://bookstore.ams.org/fourman https://www.degruyter.com/document/doi/10.1515/9783110250367/html?lang=en https://bookstore.ams.org/surv-55 https://bookstore.ams.org/gsm-20

SnapPy. https://snappy.math.uic.edu/
Mathematica. http://katlas.org/wiki/The_Mathematica_Package_KnotTheory%60 https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/ChartForATorus/
